author: By Constant Méheut
title: Pressuring France to Bring Them Home, Women Who Joined ISIS Stage Hunger Strike
description: Frenchwomen who joined the Islamic State and are now held in squalid detention camps in Syria have gone on a hunger strike to protest France’s refusal to bring them back.
content: PARIS — In a desperate appeal to France’s government, some 10 Frenchwomen who joined the Islamic State and are now being held in detention camps in Syria began a hunger strike on Saturday, protesting the government’s refusal to bring them home for trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: On the Front Page, a Wall of Grief
description: It began with one dot. Then it grew to nearly half a million. A graphic on Sunday’s front page depicts the totality of Covid’s devastation in the country.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Wins Ninth Australian Open Title
description: The victory for the top-ranked Djokovic, in three sets over the fourth-ranked Daniil Medvedev of Russia, gave him his 18th career Grand Slam title over all.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — They come nearly every year now, this new crop of challengers in men’s tennis who so desperately want to begin their time in the sun, to win the championships that everyone in the game values most and beat the three players considered the best to ever play on the biggest stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Officials confirm the first case of the South Africa variant in a New York resident.
description: The variant is more transmissible and may evade antibodies stirred by prior infections or vaccines. One other case has been detected in the state, in a Connecticut man who was hospitalized in New York City.
content: A person from a suburb east of New York City has been confirmed as the first New York resident to have been infected by a more contagious variant of the coronavirus that emerged in South Africa, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Democrats’ Big Tent Helped Them Win. Now It Threatens Biden’s Agenda.
description: The party’s ideological blend of moderates and progressives carried it to power in Washington, but elements of that coalition could block the most ambitious parts of President Biden’s agenda.
content: As he ran for president last year, Joseph R. Biden Jr. contorted his campaign to appease both wings of the Democratic Party, trying to excite progressives with an ambitious policy platform while assuring moderates he opposed structural changes to the political process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Arturo Di Modica, Sculptor of the ‘Charging Bull’, Dies at 80
description: A Sicilian-born artist, he installed the artwork in Lower Manhattan without permission. The outpouring of public support persuaded the city to keep it.
content: Arturo Di Modica, a Sicilian-born sculptor best known for “Charging Bull,” 3.5 tons of bronze belligerence that he illegally deposited in Lower Manhattan one night in 1989, died on Friday at his home in Vittoria, Italy. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Alana Holmberg
title: The Cleanest Open Ever
description: An army of workers toiled to create a safe environment at the Australian Open.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — A funny thing happened at the end of plenty of matches at the Australian Open this year: Players gathered their used water bottles and their sweat-soaked towels and put them in garbage and laundry bags rather than leaving them for someone else to clean up and, in the process, come into contact with their germs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Ivan Penn
title: His Lights Stayed on During Texas’ Storm. Now He Owes $16,752.
description: After a public outcry from people like Scott Willoughby, whose exorbitant electric bill is soon due, Gov. Greg Abbott said lawmakers should ensure Texans “do not get stuck with skyrocketing energy bills” caused by the storm.
content: SAN ANTONIO — As millions of Texans shivered in dark, cold homes over the past week while a winter storm devastated the state’s power grid and froze natural gas production, those who could still summon lights with the flick of a switch felt lucky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Israel Secretly Agrees to Fund Vaccines for Syria as Part of Prisoner Swap
description: To secure the release of an Israeli civilian held in Syria, Israel agreed to finance a supply of Russian-made Covid-19 vaccines for Damascus, an official said.
content: JERUSALEM — When a young Israeli woman was released from detention in Syria this week, after having been arrested for crossing illegally into Syria, the official story was that she had been the beneficiary of a straightforward prisoner swap. In return for her freedom, the Israeli government announced, she had been exchanged for two Syrian shepherds captured by the Israelis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Shlomo Hillel, Who Helped 120,000 Jews Flee Iraq, Dies at 97
description: Working undercover, he used bribes, fake visas and a network of smugglers to bring refugees to Israel in the late 1940s and early ’50s.
content: Shlomo Hillel, a Baghdad-born Israeli operative who in the late 1940s and early ’50s used bribes, fake visas and a network of smugglers to move more than 120,000 Jews from Iraq to Israel, died on Feb. 8 at his home in Ra’anana, Israel. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: How to Stream This Year’s Oscar Hopefuls
description: In a typical Academy Awards season, many top contenders are playing only in a few theaters when the nominations are announced. But like much of our lives these today, the way we watch movies has been upended. This year, most of the Oscar hopefuls are available for anyone to watch right now, across the country — not just in theaters, but on subscription streaming services and on video on demand.
content: In a typical Academy Awards season, many top contenders are playing only in a few theaters when the nominations are announced. But like much of our lives these today, the way we watch movies has been upended. This year, most of the Oscar hopefuls are available for anyone to watch right now, across the country — not just in theaters, but on subscription streaming services and on video on demand.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Man Who Turned Credit Card Points Into an Empire’
description: Brian Kelly has created a business dedicated to maximizing credit card rewards and airline miles. What are they worth in a pandemic — and why are they worth anything at all?
content: In recent years, travel — cheap travel, specifically — has boomed. Like all booms it has its winners (including influencers and home-sharing platforms like Airbnb) and its losers (namely locals and the environment). Somewhere in that mix is The Points Guy, Brian Kelly, who runs a blog that helps visitors navigate the sprawling, knotty and complex world of travel and credit card rewards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard and Téa Kvetenadze
title: Central Park Ice Rinks Remain Open Despite Rift With Trump, Mayor Says
description: The city reversed a decision to end the skating season abruptly. Officials have canceled contracts with the former president’s business to operate the two rinks.
content: Wistful skaters descended on Central Park on Sunday for what they thought would be their last outing on the ice for the season, after the Trump Organization abruptly announced that the two ice rinks there would close as the city moved to end its contracts following the Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Medvedev’s Australian Open Loss Shows the Men’s Tennis Gulf Is Still Strong
description: The players at the top, starting with Novak Djokovic, have yet to be significantly challenged by the new generation.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — With a lone tear streaking his right cheek, Daniil Medvedev accepted the runner-up trophy after the Australian Open men’s final on Sunday night. He stepped to the microphone and told an engaging story about nervously hitting with Novak Djokovic for the first time as a young player, when Djokovic was the men’s world No. 1 and Medvedev was on his way to a year-ending ranking of No. 655.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Art Mystery Solved: Who Wrote on Edvard Munch’s ‘The Scream’?
description: The authorship of the tiny inscription, “Could only have been painted by a madman,” was disputed. Curators in Oslo say the artist definitely wrote it himself. (But why?)
content: Edvard Munch’s “The Scream,” from 1893, is one of the world’s most famous paintings, but for years art historians have mostly ignored a tiny inscription, written in pencil, at the upper left corner of its frame, reading: “Could only have been painted by a madman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Zendaya on ‘Malcolm & Marie’ and That Toxic Relationship
description: The actress has heard both the praise for her performance and the criticism of the film. She sees it differently.
content: When Zendaya began production of “Malcolm & Marie,” the made-during-lockdown Netflix drama she stars in with John David Washington, she never imagined that it would spark both strong criticism and award-season buzz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Klein
title: Why Texas Republicans Fear the Green New Deal
description: Small government is no match for a crisis born of the state’s twin addictions to market fixes and fossil fuels.
content: Since the power went out in Texas, the state’s most prominent Republicans have tried to pin the blame for the crisis on, of all things, a sweeping progressive mobilization to fight poverty, inequality and climate change. “This shows how the Green New Deal would be a deadly deal,” Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said Wednesday on Fox News. Pointing to snow-covered solar panels, Rick Perry, a former governor who was later an energy secretary for the Trump administration, declared in a tweet “that if we humans want to keep surviving frigid winters, we are going to have to keep burning natural gas — and lots of it — for decades to come.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: On the Post-Pandemic Horizon, Could That Be … a Boom?
description: Signs of economic life are picking up, and mounds of cash are waiting to be spent as the virus loosens its grip.
content: The U.S. economy remains mired in a pandemic winter of shuttered storefronts, high unemployment and sluggish job growth. But on Wall Street and in Washington, attention is shifting to an intriguing if indistinct prospect: a post-Covid boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Garland Says as Attorney General He Would Combat Domestic Extremism
description: The judge is also expected to affirm his commitment to equal justice under the law and to vow to root out widespread discrimination.
content: WASHINGTON — Judge Merrick B. Garland plans to tell senators on Monday that he will restore the Justice Department’s commitment to equal justice under the law, combat a resurgent domestic terrorist threat and work to root out widespread discrimination should he be confirmed as attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Tennessee Man Who Served as Nazi Camp Guard Is Deported to Germany
description: The deportation of Friedrich Karl Berger capped what could be the last prosecution by the U.S. government of collaborators in Nazi war crimes.
content: A 95-year-old man who lived in Tennessee was deported to Germany on Saturday, one year after a federal judge found that he had served as an armed guard at a Nazi concentration camp where prisoners were forced to work outdoors “to the point of exhaustion and death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Virus Variants Deliver Fresh Blow to Europe’s Open Borders
description: Countries are again rushing to limit travel. That’s become a standard measure in the face of Covid threats, raising questions about whether a pillar of European Union integration can survive.
content: BRUSSELS — As new variants of the coronavirus spread rapidly, major countries are moving to reintroduce border controls, a practice that’s become Europe’s new normal during the pandemic and is chipping away at what was once the world’s largest area of free movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Stein
title: Could This Be the Lab-Made Dinner Party of Our Future?
description: A slew of start-ups are engineering faux meats, eggs and dairy products that conjure a time when we move from farm-to-table to lab-to-table.
content: I spend nearly as much time talking about how I want to stop eating meat as I do eating it. I care about animals and the environment and, even more, virtue signaling about how much I care about animals and the environment. I just don’t want to make any effort or sacrifice any pleasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss, Manny Fernandez, Ivan Penn and Rick Rojas
title: How Texas’ Drive for Energy Independence Set It Up for Disaster
description: Texas has refused to join interstate electrical grids and railed against energy regulation. Now it’s having to answer to millions of residents who were left without power in last week’s snowstorm.
content: HOUSTON — Across the plains of West Texas, the pump jacks that resemble giant bobbing hammers define not just the landscape but the state itself: Texas has been built on the oil-and-gas business for the last 120 years, ever since the discovery of oil on Spindletop Hill near Beaumont in 1901.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima Faizi and Rod Nordland
title: They Built Libraries to Honor Loved Ones, Women Felled by Bombings
description: As negotiations push forward, it is unclear whether Afghanistan can achieve peace with the Taliban while preserving gains made on women’s rights and education.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — When his soon-to-be fiancée, Najiba Hussaini, was killed in a Taliban suicide bombing in Kabul, Hussain Rezai didn’t know how to grieve for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Anlin Cheng
title: What This Wave of Anti-Asian Violence Reveals About America
description: Too often, attention to nonwhite groups is only as pressing as the injuries that they have suffered.
content: A 23-year-old Korean woman in New York was punched in the face last March and accused of having the coronavirus. More incidents followed as the virus spread, with Asian-Americans being spat on, beaten, slashed, even attacked with chemicals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: New York’s Pop-Up Concerts Kick Off With Jazz at a Vaccination Site
description: The musician Jon Batiste led a band through the Javits Center to begin half a year of unannounced performances throughout the state.
content: It seemed at first like a small, no-frills concert in a carefully controlled environment: The jazz musician Jon Batiste sitting at a piano in an auditorium at the Javits Center on Manhattan’s West Side, performing for an audience of about 50 health care workers seated in evenly spaced rows — some wearing scrubs, others Army fatigues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Airbnb Is Driving Hosts Elsewhere With Costly Pandemic Policies
description: Hurt by refunds, some are trying to cut the site out of bookings or taking legal action. The company says it is working to reduce tensions.
content: Over six years, Lorraine Luongo went from renting out a spare room in her house in Myrtle Beach, S.C., to owning and managing 10 properties that she listed on Airbnb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough
title: Fauci expects Americans could still need to wear face masks in 2022.
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, President Biden’s chief medical adviser for Covid-19, said on Sunday that Americans may still be wearing masks outside their homes a year from now, even as he predicted the country would return to “a significant degree of normality” by fall.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, President Biden’s chief medical adviser for Covid-19, said on Sunday that Americans may still be wearing masks outside their homes a year from now, even as he predicted the country would return to “a significant degree of normality” by fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Melissa Clark has three fine maximalist brownies for you to make, topped with pecans, mounded with coconut or built onto a pretzel crust.
content: Good morning. Melissa Clark wrote about the joys of maximalist brownies for The Times recently, and at least one of the three recipes that accompany the article ought to come out of your oven this afternoon: either pecan pie brownies, coconut macaroon brownies or salted pretzel brownies (above). Melissa has love for the understated, simple brownie, of course. But she’s pandemic-tired. She longs for indulgence. When it comes to brownies right now, she writes, “Make mine as gooey, chewy and opulently embellished as they can be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sign of Online Shouting
description: Beware the shark that lurks in Barbara Lin’s Monday puzzle!
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is a tricky grid from Barbara Lin, who’s also made Thursday and Sunday puzzles for The New York Times. The theme is straightforward enough for a Monday, especially with a clear revealer (which I needed, full confession). But I think some of the cluing is pretty advanced, with a lot of interesting words very unassumingly slipping in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: The Indian vaccine giant expected to supply much of the world warns that it has been directed to put its country’s needs ahead of exports.
description: ‘Dear countries & governments,’ tweeted Adar Poonawalla of the Serum Institute, ‘I humbly request you to please be patient.’
content: The chief executive of the Indian pharmaceutical giant that dozens of countries are counting on to supply them with Covid-19 vaccines said on Sunday that their deliveries might be delayed because it had been “directed”  to fill domestic needs ahead of export orders.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Storm Exposing a Nation Primed for Catastrophe
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 21, 2021.
content: “That sense of mastery over nature has been so seriously challenged by this pandemic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Yourgrau
title: Head Back to the Past With Old-Time Radio
description: A wealth of radio shows, constructed from dialogue and sound effects, and with a touch of narration and music, is free on the internet.
content: In the image and video cacophony of our world, there’s an old-fashioned medium that rouses and works with our own powers of imagination, one that suits these cooped-up inner-world days of ours. It’s radio drama, especially from its golden age, in the 1930s through the ’50s, when radio was king of home entertainment. Thanks to the internet, the archival wealth of such shows — constructed from dialogue and sound effects, with a touch of narration and music — is freely available. Here are six to enjoy whenever and wherever, indoors or out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 22, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Tom Konchalski, Dogged Basketball Scout, Dies at 74
description: He traveled to schools, camps and schoolyards to evaluate high school players, and his reports were essential to college coaches in their recruiting.
content: For more than 40 years, Tom Konchalski was a fixture in gyms, summer camps and tournaments from Maine to West Virginia, a soft-spoken high school basketball scout whose newsletter was required reading for college coaches craving insights about potential recruits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
title: In Israeli Election, a Chance for Arabs to Gain Influence, or Lose It
description: Jewish politicians, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, are courting Arab Israeli voters, and some Arab politicians are prepared to work with them.
content: KAFR KANNA, Israel — Mansour Abbas, a conservative Muslim, is an unlikely political partner for the leaders of the Jewish state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Santaniello
title: With Charlie McAvoy, the Bruins Filled a Void From Within
description: After the departures of two key defensemen in free agency, McAvoy, 23, is playing more minutes and is tied for the assists lead on first-place Boston.
content: In one short off-season, the Boston Bruins lost Zdeno Chara, their 14-year captain and shutdown defenseman, and Torey Krug, the quarterback of their perennially potent power play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: What a Texas Plumber Faces Now: A State Full of Burst Pipes
description: Since a winter storm and hard freeze swept through the state last week, knocking out power and heat, homeowners have swamped plumbers with urgent repair calls.
content: HOUSTON — Randy Calazans is one of the hottest commodities in Texas right now. He’s a plumber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: How Investigative Journalism Flourished in Hostile Russia
description: A new wave of news outlets has used conventional, and unconventional, methods to pierce the veil of Putin’s power.
content: The Russian language has introduced a few words that in recent years have been widely used and misused in English: disinformation, kompromat, Novichok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: China Censors the Internet. So Why Doesn’t Russia?
description: The Kremlin has constructed an entire infrastructure of repression but has not displaced Western apps. Instead, it is turning to outright intimidation.
content: MOSCOW — Margarita Simonyan, the editor in chief of the Kremlin-controlled RT television network, recently called on the government to block access to Western social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: He Writes Unreliable Narrators Because He Is One, Too
description: Viet Thanh Nguyen won the Pulitzer for his debut, “The Sympathizer,” recognition that was great for his career and bad for his writing. Now he’s back with its subversive sequel, “The Committed.”
content: In one of Viet Thanh Nguyen’s earliest memories, he is on a boat leaving Saigon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Erik Prince, Trump Ally, Denies Role in Libya Mercenary Operation
description: In an interview, the contractor pushed back against a United Nations report accusing him of breaching a decade-old arms embargo on Libya.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Responding to accusations by United Nations investigators that he violated an international arms embargo, Erik Prince, the Blackwater Worldwide founder and prominent supporter of Donald J. Trump, denied playing any role in an $80 million mercenary operation in Libya in 2019. And he insisted that key findings of the U.N. investigation were entirely wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: How Democrats Are Already Maneuvering to Shape Biden’s First Supreme Court Pick
description: Party leaders are urging President Biden not only to consider racial diversity in potential Supreme Court nominees, but to look at candidates who don’t come from a traditional Ivy League background.
content: WASHINGTON — After meeting in the Oval Office earlier this month with President Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris and his fellow senior House Democrats, Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina made a beeline to Ms. Harris’s office in the West Wing to privately raise a topic that did not come up during their group discussion: the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A $900 Million Mistake
description: How Citigroup gave away nearly $1 billion by accident.
content: Hope you’re all staying warm. Here’s your quick roundup of business and tech news to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The U.S. Covid toll nears half a million.
content: More Americans have died of Covid-19 than on the battlefields of World War I, World War II and the Vietnam War combined. No other country has counted so many deaths in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Batman: The Animated Series’ Predicted the Bat-Future
description: This Saturday morning cartoon, now streaming on HBO Max, redefined the caped crusader years before he became one of the world’s most popular and endlessly recycled characters.
content: Before Robert Pattinson and Ben Affleck and Christian Bale, there was Kevin Conroy and the Gotham City of “Batman: The Animated Series.” The Warner Bros. series, which ran from 1992-1995 on Fox Kids, arrived on HBO Max in January. A Saturday morning cartoon that was also a super-stylized foray into the noir genre, it brought the Dark Knight version of the caped crusader to television, redefining a formerly earnest, occasionally silly TV hero and foreshadowing the ever darker iterations to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Settlement Reached in Suit Accusing James Franco of Sexual Misconduct
description: Two former students of Mr. Franco’s have agreed to drop their claims that he had intimidated them into performing explicit sex scenes. Mr. Franco has denied the allegations.
content: Two former students who filed a lawsuit in 2019 accusing the actor and filmmaker James Franco of subjecting them to sexually exploitative auditions and film shoots at an acting and film school that he founded have agreed to drop their claims against him as part of a settlement reached earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.’, Fictional Britney Spears Seeks Apologies From Cruz, Cuomo and Carano
description: “Saturday Night Live” gave several famous people the chance to say sorry on an episode hosted by Regé-Jean Page of “Bridgerton.”
content: It has been a memorable week or so for public figures committing misdeeds, and “Saturday Night Live” gave a few of them a forum to apologize on a fictional talk show called “Oops, You Did It Again,” hosted by the relatively blameless Britney Spears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Seven Hundred Leagues Beneath Titan’s Methane Seas
description: Mars, Shmars; this voyager is looking forward to a submarine ride under the icebergs on Saturn’s strange moon.
content: What could be more exciting than flying a helicopter over the deserts of Mars? How about playing Captain Nemo on Saturn’s large, foggy moon Titan — plumbing the depths of a methane ocean, dodging hydrocarbon icebergs and exploring an ancient, frigid shoreline of organic goo a billion miles from the sun?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: The pace of U.S. vaccinations has drastically slowed, hampered by snow and power outages.
description: The rate of Covid-19 vaccinations in the United States, which had been accelerating after a chaotic start, has quickly fallen after a winter storm blew through much of the country, closing vaccine sites and delaying shipments of millions of doses.
content: The rate of Covid-19 vaccinations in the United States, which had been accelerating after a chaotic start, has quickly fallen after a winter storm blew through much of the country, closing vaccine sites and delaying shipments of millions of doses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb, Deborah Leiderman and Sarah Bahr
title: Woody Allen, Mia Farrow, Soon-Yi Previn, Dylan Farrow: A Timeline
description: A look at major events in the complicated history of the director, his children and the Farrow family as a new documentary revisits the case.
content: For years, the account given by Woody Allen’s then-7-year-old adopted daughter Dylan Farrow in the days following Aug. 4, 1992, when she says he sexually assaulted her, has been central to her case against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Mayersohn
title: Thinking of an Electric Car? Take Your Choice
description: Even before G.M. announced it would work toward eliminating emissions from its vehicles, more automakers were putting E. V.s in their showrooms. Here’s a roundup.
content: The announcement by General Motors last month that it would work to phase out fossil-fuel vehicles by 2035 added a note of urgency to the shift to electric vehicles. Much of that is driven by regulatory action, as states and countries move to ban the sale of new petroleum-powered vehicles in the next 15 or 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Harmon
title: Hot Dish! The Newspaper Makes a Great Trivet
description: Once the paper is hot off the presses, use it to cool down your pots.
content: Most people are doing a lot of cooking at home right now. These short cold days are the ideal time to enjoy steaming soup, warm roasted veggies and toasty bowls of comforting pasta. Newspaper is a good insulator, so why not turn it into a useful item that will protect your table from scorching dishes? (The reader Rhonda Fadum from Boulder, Colo., suggested this idea for a newspaper craft activity.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Paid It No Mind and Kept My Head Low, Glued to My Music’
description: Running late to work, quarters to spare should an emergency arise and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Luke Broadwater
title: The Lost Hours: How Confusion and Inaction at the Capitol Delayed a Troop Deployment
description: As violence grew out of control on Jan. 6, the head of the Capitol Police made an urgent request for the National Guard. It took nearly two hours to be approved.
content: WASHINGTON — At 1:09 p.m. on Jan. 6, minutes after protesters had burst through the barricades around the U.S. Capitol and began using the steel debris to assault the officers standing guard, the chief of the Capitol Police made a desperate call for backup. It took nearly two hours for officials to approve the deployment of the National Guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Ben Dooley
title: Boeing Calls for Global Grounding of 777s Equipped With One Engine Model
description: The company said 128 jets powered by a particular Pratt & Whitney engine should get inspections. Japanese regulators ordered that the planes be grounded.
content: Boeing said on Sunday that all 128 of its 777 jetliners powered by a particular Pratt & Whitney engine model should be grounded worldwide until the Federal Aviation Administration determines the best way to inspect the engines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: The Story of ‘Team Molly’
description: While her daughter was hospitalized, one mother built more room for our national grief.
content: Strapped in the front seat of an ambulance as her daughter lay injured in the back, Kaye Steinsapir took out her phone and began to type.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Coronavirus, Texas, Mars: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Visit a Botanical Garden and Brew Kombucha
description: This week, celebrate the life of Malcolm X, brush up on your photography skills or bake marshmallow brownies.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: A Ripple Effect of Loss: U.S. Covid Deaths Approach 500,000
description: Twice as many Americans have died as early worst-case projections.
content: CHICAGO — A nation numbed by misery and loss is confronting a number that still has the power to shock: 500,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Positive Coronavirus Test? Canadians Worry Their Neighbors Will Find Out
description: The fear of public shaming is becoming so prevalent in some Canadian provinces that doctors worry it is driving virus cases underground.
content: For a time, Cortland Cronk, 26, was Canada’s most famous — and infamous — coronavirus patient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1946: Septuplet Rumor Fools Reporters in Paris
description: Newspaper reporters fell for a practical joke, discovering the truth only after scouring the city for a woman who had given birth to seven babies.
content: Paris was subjected to an intensive search last night by French and foreign newspaper reporters who forgot international politics and other forms of news when the rumor spread that somewhere in the city a woman had given birth to seven babies, or septuplets. At midnight the frantic search was still going on but no such fertile woman had been found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: Lake Tahoe’s Sunshine Made for a Great Scene, but Bad Ice
description: After several players and officials stumbled on soft ice in the first period, an N.H.L. game that started on Saturday afternoon was delayed, ending after midnight Eastern time.
content: STATELINE, Nev. — The N.H.L. set out for a grand outdoor spectacle at Lake Tahoe. But after one period of Saturday’s game between the Colorado Avalanche and the Vegas Golden Knights, the venture became a bid for longest intermission: The remainder of the game had to be played under lights instead of in daylight, and it spilled into Sunday in much of North America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Is This the End of Tipping?
description: The restaurant industry is in crisis. But some see how bad things are for servers — including “maskual harassment” — as a unique chance to make life better.
content: On a hot night last summer, Shelly Ortiz gulped down water, put on two masks and tried to muster the excitement she used to feel heading into work at the Clever Koi, a hip ramen-and-cocktail spot in Phoenix. She loved the banter with co-workers, and the regular customers whose orders she’d memorized. During the pandemic, though, those joys had been subsumed by her anxiety about contracting the virus while still making ends meet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: In His ‘Second Career,’ Filip Polasek Wins His First Grand Slam Title
description: Polasek, who had effectively retired after the 2013 season because of an injury, won the Australian Open men’s doubles championship with his partner, Ivan Dodig.
content: Playing in his first Grand Slam final 16 years after turning professional, Filip Polasek was ready for the moment, and nearly every ball that came his way.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: In this letter, and the follow-up correspondence, Mr. Kabila urges President Bush to work with Dan Gertler to try to help Congo reach a peace agreement to a war then playing out in Congo.
content: In this letter, and the follow-up correspondence, Mr. Kabila urges President Bush to work with Dan Gertler to try to help Congo reach a peace agreement to a war then playing out in Congo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Valentino-DeVries, Denise Lu, Eleanor Lutz and Alex Leeds Matthews
title: A Small Group of Militants’ Outsize Role in the Capitol Attack
description: Prosecutors have highlighted two militant groups — the Oath Keepers and the Proud Boys — as being the most organized in last month’s assault.
content: Prosecutors have highlighted two militant groups — the Oath Keepers and the Proud Boys — as being the most organized in last month’s assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Join Clubhouse! Umm, What is Clubhouse?
description: A simple explainer to the newest, buzziest social media app around.
content: Last summer, the social media app Clubhouse had just a few thousand users, mostly Silicon Valley tech workers and venture capitalists who wanted to connect with one another during the pandemic. Today, it has millions of  users, a valuation of roughly $1 billion and a ton of buzz. Both the Tesla chief executive Elon Musk and the Facebook head Mark Zuckerberg recently appeared on Clubhouse, causing such a stir that the platform nearly crashed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hello? Is There Anybody Out There?
description: Readers respond to a column by Farhad Manjoo about looking for intelligent life in the universe.
content: To the Editor:
